Text_Numeracy: In my late 50s I had my gall bladder out but didn't get sick until they came to wheel me to the recovery room. Everything thereafter for about 18 hours was a whirlwind of pain, nausea, fever cold sweats and abject terror. Patients be wary of what you read on the Internet about your symptoms. So, it was determined a few months later I had what is called late gall bladder syndrome, which boils down to too much bile sloshing about with the gall bladder gone. An outpatient procedure to cut a sphincter and allow more drainage fixed the problem. 20/20 hindsight, tour cameras during the original surgery showed the problem but no one looked for it or asked me about my symptoms until I reached my limit. When they did, I had solved after a lengthy conversation. Knowledge of health issues is one thing. The ability understand what goes on behind the curtains of medicine is another. Patients have to not only ask for help they, unfortunately, have to plead for it. My experience wasn't unique the nurses told me. Like some doctors, they had a rough time believing it. They do now. I guess you could say I taught them. Never stop asking.
